abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Gujarat Urban Development Project in
            India. The project aimed at helping reduce the deficits in
            urban shelter, infrastructure, and services in the main
            centers of the state. To this effect it included the
            following items addressing a complex set of sub-objectives:
            (i) development of 100 hectare in six cities, (ii) town
            planning schemes covering 570 hectare in three cities
            including land readjustment and basic infrastructure, (iii)
            upgrading of 250 hectare of slums in five cities, (iv)
            improvement of solid waste disposal services in five cities,
            (v) other urban infrastructure (water supply, sewerage,
            storm drainage, etc. in four areas, and (vi) institutional
            strengthening at local and state level through technical
            assistance. Bank’s performance was unsatisfactory.
            Borrower's performance was unsatisfactory. The key
            lessons learned from the project were: (a) the project
            lacked realism, partly due to hasty preparation apparently
            related to  International Development Association (IDA)
            concern to have a large impact on the sector quickly; (b)
            the project should have had less components and objectives,
            to allow for the weakness of the implementing agencies which
            were already evident at Project preparation; (c) the
            implementation prospects for complex projects involving
            urban services and investments would be strengthened if, at
            project launch, a strong intermediary capacity is
            established; and (d) the monitoring framework should be
            aimed at ensuring that supervision missions avoid spending
            excessive time checking on procurement status and physical
            progress in many sub-projects, and can focus on more
            strategic issues.
